displaytitle: Portrait of the Chan Founding Patriarch Bodhidharma
displaydate: 1680 (stone); late 19th to first half of 20th century (rubbing)
medium: Hanging scroll; ink rubbing on paper
inscribed:
Bottom, left:
Feng Xiu 馮繡 (late Qing dynasty)
庚申[1680]季春四明馮繡薰沭敬寫
長安楊玉璞刻
Feng Xiu of Siming [i.e., Ningbo] purified himself and sketched this in the last spring month of the gengshen cyclical year. Engraved by Yang Yupu of Chang’an.
Notes:
1. Without knowing Feng Xiu’s life dates, it difficult to confirm the gengshen cyclical year corresponds to 1680.
Rubbing seals:
“Feng Xiu [zhi] yin” 馮繡[之]印, sq. relief
[][] sq. intaglio

Top:
Zhu Jiyi 朱集義 (act. 17th century)
達摩祖師像
座中龍象戲青蓮，指點宗風十幾傳
脫屣金沙塵世外，拂衣雙樹白雲邊
凌空錫杖同霞駐，說法優曇過雨妍
遲我百年方丈約，竹床茶灶共溪烟
閭山朱集義題
Portrait of the Master Bodhidharma
The seated Master plays with a green lotus-leaf to indicate the dozen lessons of his regulations.
Slipping off his shoes by the golden-sand river beyond this dusty world, 
shaking out his robe under the twin sala trees at the edge of the clouds.
His abbot’s staff soars into the sky to dwell with the rosy mists,
his preaching of the law is like the [rarely-flowering] udumbra tree in bloom after rain.
Delay your death with the abbot’s discipline,
bamboo couch and stove for tea together by streams and mists.
Inscribed by Zhu Jiyi of Mount Lu
(translated by Amy McNair in Latter Days of the Law [1994], p. 289)
Rubbing seals:
“Zhu Jiyi yin” 朱集義印, sq. intaglio
“[] an” []庵, sq. relief

texts.textentryhtml: Bodhidharma is depicted as a literatus seated on a root wood chair with loosely crossed legs with his shoes on. He holds a brush in one hand and a leaf to write on in the other. A young attendant stands at one side holding up an inkstone.
